title: Jeremiah Chapter 31 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Jeremiah chapter 31 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Jeremiah Chapter 31 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Jeremiah Chapter 31.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 31:3, how has the LORD loved Israel?
options: With an everlasting love
With a temporary love
With a conditional love
With a doubtful love
questions.correctAnswer: With an everlasting love
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 31:3 states that the LORD has loved Israel with an everlasting love, drawing them with lovingkindness.

questions.question: What will the LORD do for the virgin of Israel according to Jeremiah 31:4?
options: Build her up and adorn her with tabrets
Destroy her cities
Send her into exile
Make her a queen
questions.correctAnswer: Build her up and adorn her with tabrets
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 31:4 promises that the LORD will build up the virgin of Israel and she will be adorned with tabrets to go forth in dances.

questions.question: Where shall the watchmen cry to go up according to Jeremiah 31:6?
options: Zion unto the LORD our God
Babylon to seek refuge
Egypt for safety
Mount Sinai to worship
questions.correctAnswer: Zion unto the LORD our God
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 31:6 says the watchmen upon mount Ephraim will cry, 'Arise ye, and let us go up to Zion unto the LORD our God.'

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 31:8, what kinds of people will the LORD gather?
options: The blind and the lame, the woman with child and her that travaileth with child
Only the strong and healthy
Only the young men
Only the priests and elders
questions.correctAnswer: The blind and the lame, the woman with child and her that travaileth with child
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 31:8 says the LORD will gather from the north country the blind, lame, and women with child together.

questions.question: In Jeremiah 31:10, how does the LORD keep Israel?
options: As a shepherd doth his flock
Like a king his subjects
Like a warrior his army
Like a merchant his goods
questions.correctAnswer: As a shepherd doth his flock
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 31:10 compares the LORD's care for Israel to a shepherd keeping his flock.

questions.question: What will the people do in the height of Zion according to Jeremiah 31:12?
options: Sing and flow together to the goodness of the LORD
Mourn and fast
Build altars to idols
Remain silent
questions.correctAnswer: Sing and flow together to the goodness of the LORD
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 31:12 tells that they shall come and sing in Zion, flowing together to the goodness of the LORD.

questions.question: What will the LORD do with the mourning of the people according to Jeremiah 31:13?
options: Turn their mourning into joy
Increase their mourning
Ignore their mourning
Forget their mourning
questions.correctAnswer: Turn their mourning into joy
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 31:13 promises the LORD will turn mourning into joy and comfort them.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 31:15, who is weeping and refusing to be comforted?
options: Rahel
Miriam
Esther
Deborah
questions.correctAnswer: Rahel
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 31:15 describes Rahel weeping bitterly for her children and refusing to be comforted.

questions.question: What does the LORD say He will do with His law in Jeremiah 31:33?
options: Put it in their inward parts and write it in their hearts
Destroy it
Hide it in the mountains
Give it to the priests only
questions.correctAnswer: Put it in their inward parts and write it in their hearts
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 31:33 says the LORD will put His law within them and write it on their hearts.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 31:29 states that the children will be punished for the sins of their fathers.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 31:29 explains that in those days, people will no longer say children are punished for their fathers' sins; each dies for their own iniquity.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 31:31 speaks of the LORD making a new covenant with Israel and Judah.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 31:31 clearly states the LORD will make a new covenant with the house of Israel and Judah.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 31:34 says that all people will know the LORD from the least to the greatest and their sins will be forgiven.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 31:34 states that all will know the LORD from least to greatest and He will forgive their iniquity and remember their sin no more.

questions.question: Complete the verse from Jeremiah 31:1: 'At the same time, saith the LORD, will I be the God of all the families of _______, and they shall be my people.'
options: Israel
Judah
Ephraim
Babylon
questions.correctAnswer: Israel
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 31:1 clearly states the LORD will be God of all the families of Israel.

questions.question: What will the people plant upon the mountains of Samaria according to Jeremiah 31:5?
options: Vines
Olive trees
Wheat
Barley
questions.correctAnswer: Vines
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 31:5 says people shall plant vines upon the mountains of Samaria.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 31:22, what new thing has the LORD created in the earth?
options: A woman shall compass a man
A new star
A new mountain
A new sea
questions.correctAnswer: A woman shall compass a man
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 31:22 states the LORD has created a new thing in the earth: a woman shall compass a man.

medium.title: Jeremiah Chapter 31 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Jeremiah Chapter 31 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with discouragement due to past mistakes. Based on Jeremiah 31, what biblical truth would you share about God's forgiveness and restoration?
options: God will remember their sins forever and hold them accountable.
God places His law in their hearts and forgives their iniquity, remembering their sin no more.
They must earn forgiveness through their own efforts.
Forgiveness is only for those who never sin again.
questions.correctAnswer: God places His law in their hearts and forgives their iniquity, remembering their sin no more.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 31:33-34 teaches that God will put His law in their inward parts and forgive their iniquity, remembering their sin no more, emphasizing God's grace and restoration. This is supported by verses 31:31-34.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 31 teach us about God's faithfulness in difficult times?
options: God abandons His people when they stray.
God watches over His people to both discipline and build them up.
God only punishes without hope of restoration.
God’s promises are conditional on perfect obedience.
questions.correctAnswer: God watches over His people to both discipline and build them up.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 31:28 explains that God watches over Israel to pluck up and break down, but also to build and plant, showing His ongoing faithfulness even through discipline. Verses 31:18-20 also reflect God's mercy after chastisement.

questions.question: In what way does Jeremiah 31 encourage believers to respond to God's loving kindness?
options: By becoming self-righteous and judging others.
By repenting and turning back to God with a humble heart.
By ignoring God’s discipline and continuing in sin.
By distancing themselves from fellowship.
questions.correctAnswer: By repenting and turning back to God with a humble heart.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 31:18-19 shows Ephraim acknowledging chastisement and repenting, reflecting a humble heart that returns to God. This demonstrates the appropriate response to God's loving kindness (31:3).

questions.question: A believer feels overwhelmed by sorrow. What comfort from Jeremiah 31 can you share about God’s ability to transform mourning into joy?
options: God will always leave sorrow as it is.
God promises to turn mourning into joy and comfort His people.
Sorrow is permanent and cannot be relieved.
Only time, not God, can heal sorrow.
questions.correctAnswer: God promises to turn mourning into joy and comfort His people.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 31:13 clearly states that God will turn mourning into joy, comfort His people, and cause them to rejoice from their sorrow, demonstrating His power to restore hope.

questions.question: What does Jeremiah 31 teach about God's covenant relationship with His people?
options: God’s covenant is based only on external observance of the law.
God will make a new covenant writing His law on their hearts and being their God.
The covenant is only for the fathers and not their descendants.
God will reject His people permanently if they sin.
questions.correctAnswer: God will make a new covenant writing His law on their hearts and being their God.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 31:31-33 describes the new covenant where God writes His law in their hearts and will be their God, emphasizing an internal and relational covenant rather than external observance alone.

questions.question: True or False: According to Jeremiah 31, God promises to gather His scattered people and care for them like a shepherd cares for his flock.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 31:10 states that God who scattered Israel will gather and keep them as a shepherd does his flock, highlighting God's protective and caring nature.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 31 describe God's attitude toward His people when He disciplines them?
options: He is angry and forgets them.
He is like a father who remembers and has mercy on them.
He punishes without compassion.
He abandons them permanently.
questions.correctAnswer: He is like a father who remembers and has mercy on them.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 31:9 and 31:20 depict God as a father to Israel who remembers them and has compassion even after speaking against them, showing tender mercy despite discipline.

questions.question: A believer is confused about how the new covenant will change their relationship with God. What does Jeremiah 31 say about knowing the Lord under this new covenant?
options: Everyone will have to be taught by others to know the Lord.
All will know the Lord personally, from the least to the greatest.
Only priests will know the Lord.
The knowledge of the Lord will decrease over time.
questions.correctAnswer: All will know the Lord personally, from the least to the greatest.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 31:34 explains that under the new covenant, everyone will know the Lord directly, eliminating the need for teaching each other about Him, highlighting personal relationship with God.

questions.question: What practical teaching about perseverance through trials can be drawn from Jeremiah 31:16-17?
options: There is no hope after hardship.
God promises that the work of suffering will be rewarded and there is hope for restoration.
Sorrow must remain without relief.
Trials mean God has rejected you permanently.
questions.correctAnswer: God promises that the work of suffering will be rewarded and there is hope for restoration.
questions.explanation: Verses 31:16-17 encourage believers to refrain from despair because God promises reward for their work and hope of return, teaching perseverance through trials with trust in God's faithfulness.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 31 encourage believers regarding honesty and integrity in daily life?
options: It says dishonesty will be overlooked if done in secret.
It emphasizes that each person will be accountable for their own actions, not others'.
It encourages blaming others for one’s own sins.
It teaches that children bear their parents’ guilt.
questions.correctAnswer: It emphasizes that each person will be accountable for their own actions, not others'.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 31:29-30 clarifies that people will die for their own iniquity, not for others', encouraging personal responsibility and integrity.

questions.question: A believer questions how God provides for the needs of His people. What does Jeremiah 31 say about God's provision?
options: God will withhold provision to teach hard lessons.
God will satisfy the soul with goodness and provide abundance.
Provision depends solely on human effort.
Provision is only for the priests.
questions.correctAnswer: God will satisfy the soul with goodness and provide abundance.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 31:14 and 31:12 describe God satiating the soul of priests and His people with goodness, including wheat, wine, and oil, symbolizing abundant provision.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 31 teaches that God’s creation and laws of nature guarantee the permanence of His covenant people.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 31:35-36 uses the order of the sun, moon, and stars as a metaphor for the certainty that God's covenant people will not cease to be a nation, demonstrating divine faithfulness.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 31 encourage believers to engage in fellowship and community life after restoration?
options: By isolating themselves to avoid sin.
By dwelling together as husbandmen and shepherds in their cities.
By focusing only on personal holiness without regard for others.
By avoiding communal responsibilities.
questions.correctAnswer: By dwelling together as husbandmen and shepherds in their cities.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 31:24 speaks of people dwelling together in cities as husbandmen and those who go forth with flocks, encouraging community life and shared labor.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Jeremiah 31:3 states, 'The LORD hath appeared of old unto me, saying, Yea, I have loved thee with an ________ love.'
options: everlasting
conditional
temporary
uncertain
questions.correctAnswer: everlasting
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 31:3 clearly states that God's love is everlasting, emphasizing His eternal commitment to His people.

questions.question: What does Jeremiah 31 teach about the role of prayer and praise in trusting God during restoration?
options: Prayer and praise are unnecessary when God is restoring.
Believers should sing with gladness, shout, and praise the Lord for His salvation.
Prayer should only be done in private and never publicly.
Praise is only for the priests.
questions.correctAnswer: Believers should sing with gladness, shout, and praise the Lord for His salvation.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 31:7 calls for singing with gladness and shouting praise for the salvation of God's people, showing the importance of communal prayer and rejoicing.

hard.title: Jeremiah Chapter 31 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Jeremiah Chapter 31.

questions.question: In Jeremiah 31:3, the LORD declares His love as 'everlasting.' What Hebrew phrase is often translated as 'everlasting love,' and what is its theological significance?
options: Chesed (lovingkindness), indicating a covenantal, steadfast love
Emet (truth), showing God's faithfulness
Racham (compassion), denoting mercy
Hesed ve'emet (lovingkindness and truth), emphasizing completeness
questions.correctAnswer: Chesed (lovingkindness), indicating a covenantal, steadfast love
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 31:3 highlights the LORD's 'everlasting love' which in Hebrew is often related to 'chesed,' a covenantal lovingkindness that denotes steadfast, faithful love beyond human limitations.

questions.question: Jeremiah 31:31 introduces the concept of a 'new covenant.' How does this covenant differ from the Mosaic covenant according to verses 31-34?
options: The new covenant involves God's law written on hearts instead of tablets of stone
The new covenant requires stricter adherence to the law
The new covenant is only for the priests and Levites
The new covenant abolishes the Ten Commandments
questions.correctAnswer: The new covenant involves God's law written on hearts instead of tablets of stone
questions.explanation: Verses 31-34 contrast the old covenant, written on tablets and broken by the people, with the new covenant where God writes His law inwardly on their hearts, signifying an internal transformation.

questions.question: What historical and cultural significance does the 'virgin of Israel' imagery in Jeremiah 31:4 and 31:21 carry in the context of ancient Near Eastern prophetic literature?
options: It symbolizes the nation’s purity and readiness for restoration after exile
It refers to an actual young woman who will lead Israel
It indicates Israel’s complete destruction
It is a metaphor for the temple only
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes the nation’s purity and readiness for restoration after exile
questions.explanation: The 'virgin of Israel' metaphor represents Israel as a pure, unspoiled bride who will be rebuilt and restored, a common prophetic image of renewal and hope after judgment.

questions.question: Jeremiah 31:6-7 contains a call from the 'watchmen upon the mount Ephraim.' What is the literary device used here and its function?
options: A prophetic exhortation using personification to call for communal restoration
An example of hyperbole to emphasize suffering
A parable illustrating Israel’s wandering
A lament expressing loss
questions.correctAnswer: A prophetic exhortation using personification to call for communal restoration
questions.explanation: The watchmen crying out personify Israel’s leaders or prophets, signaling a call to action and communal return to God, characteristic of prophetic exhortation.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 31:10 use shepherd imagery, and what is its significance in the biblical tradition?
options: It depicts God as a shepherd who gathers and keeps His flock, symbolizing care and protection
It portrays Israel as shepherds ruling over nations
It contrasts false shepherds with God's judgment
It refers to literal shepherds in ancient Judah
questions.correctAnswer: It depicts God as a shepherd who gathers and keeps His flock, symbolizing care and protection
questions.explanation: The shepherd metaphor in verse 10 aligns with longstanding biblical symbolism where God is the caring shepherd who gathers scattered Israel and protects them, highlighting restoration.

questions.question: Jeremiah 31:15 references Rachel weeping for her children. Which New Testament event does this prophecy foreshadow, as cited in Matthew 2:18?
options: The massacre of the infants by King Herod in Bethlehem
The baptism of Jesus in the Jordan
The crucifixion of Jesus
The Pentecost outpouring
questions.correctAnswer: The massacre of the infants by King Herod in Bethlehem
questions.explanation: Matthew 2:18 directly quotes Jeremiah 31:15 when describing Rachel’s lamentation as a prophetic foreshadowing of Herod’s killing of male infants in Bethlehem.

questions.question: Jeremiah 31:22 contains the phrase 'A woman shall compass a man.' What is the likely literary or symbolic meaning of this expression in the context of Israel’s restoration?
options: It symbolizes a new and unexpected reversal of roles or a fresh divine act
It literally predicts an unusual battle tactic
It is a reference to a foreign queen conquering Israel
It signifies Israel’s defeat and subjugation
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes a new and unexpected reversal of roles or a fresh divine act
questions.explanation: The phrase is cryptic but likely symbolizes God's sovereign ability to enact a new and surprising restoration, overturning expectations, a theme common in prophetic literature.

questions.question: Jeremiah 31:27-28 uses agricultural imagery about sowing and watching over Israel. How does this reflect the covenantal relationship between God and Israel?
options: It illustrates both judgment and restoration, showing God’s active care and discipline
It describes an agricultural festival
It predicts Israel’s complete destruction
It denotes a harvest ritual for priests
questions.correctAnswer: It illustrates both judgment and restoration, showing God’s active care and discipline
questions.explanation: The imagery of sowing, plucking up, and building reflects God’s dual role as judge and restorer, emphasizing His continuous involvement in Israel’s covenantal fate.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 31:29-30, how is individual responsibility for sin emphasized in contrast to previous generational views?
options: Each person will die for their own iniquity, not for their father’s sins
Children will bear the punishment for their ancestors
Sin is hereditary and unavoidable
Only priests bear sin responsibility
questions.correctAnswer: Each person will die for their own iniquity, not for their father’s sins
questions.explanation: These verses reject the proverb that children suffer for their parents’ sins and affirm individual accountability, a significant theological development.

questions.question: Jeremiah 31:34 states 'they shall all know me, from the least of them unto the greatest of them.' How does this universal knowledge relate to the new covenant?
options: It indicates an intimate, direct relationship between God and all His people without intermediaries
It means only priests will have knowledge of God
It refers to hidden knowledge revealed only to the elders
It indicates a future temple teaching program
questions.correctAnswer: It indicates an intimate, direct relationship between God and all His people without intermediaries
questions.explanation: The new covenant promises that all people will personally know God, removing barriers and priestly exclusivity, fulfilling Jeremiah 31:34’s declaration.

questions.question: Jeremiah 31:35-37 uses cosmic imagery about the sun, moon, and stars. What is the purpose of this imagery in the context of Israel's fate?
options: To affirm the irrevocable nature of God’s covenant with Israel
To predict an astronomical event
To imply Israel’s destruction is certain
To describe a pagan ritual
questions.correctAnswer: To affirm the irrevocable nature of God’s covenant with Israel
questions.explanation: The imagery emphasizes that just as the natural order is established and constant, so is God’s commitment to Israel’s enduring existence.

questions.question: Jeremiah 31:40 describes a holy valley that 'shall not be plucked up, nor thrown down any more for ever.' What does this imply about Jerusalem’s future?
options: Jerusalem will experience permanent peace and sanctity after restoration
The valley will be used for sacrifices only
The city will be abandoned
The valley will be destroyed again
questions.correctAnswer: Jerusalem will experience permanent peace and sanctity after restoration
questions.explanation: The passage promises a future where Jerusalem’s sacred places are preserved permanently, symbolizing lasting restoration and divine presence.

questions.question: In Jeremiah 31:18-20, Ephraim expresses remorse for his chastisement. What does this reveal about the prophetic theme of repentance in Jeremiah?
options: Repentance leads to restoration and God’s mercy
Repentance is futile and ignored
Chastisement is permanent punishment without hope
Repentance is only for priests
questions.correctAnswer: Repentance leads to restoration and God’s mercy
questions.explanation: Ephraim’s lament and God’s response in verse 20 show that sincere repentance provokes God’s compassionate mercy, a recurrent theme in Jeremiah.

questions.question: Jeremiah 31:12 describes the people coming to Zion and their souls being 'as a watered garden.' What literary device is being used here, and what does it represent?
options: Simile, representing spiritual refreshment and abundance
Metaphor, indicating drought
Hyperbole, exaggerating hardship
Irony, showing false hope
questions.correctAnswer: Simile, representing spiritual refreshment and abundance
questions.explanation: The comparison of souls to a watered garden uses simile to convey revitalization and joy resulting from God’s goodness upon restoration.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 31:1 emphasizes that the LORD will be God only of the tribe of Judah and not all Israel.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 31:1 states that the LORD will be God of all the families of Israel, extending beyond just Judah to the entire nation.

theological.title: Jeremiah Chapter 31 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Jeremiah Chapter 31 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 31, how does God describe His love for Israel?
options: Everlasting love
Conditional love
Temporary love
Disciplinary love
questions.correctAnswer: Everlasting love
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 31:3 states that the LORD has loved Israel with an everlasting love; this reflects God's eternal, unchanging commitment to His people, consistent with passages such as Romans 8:38-39, Ephesians 2:4-5, Psalm 136:1, and John 3:16.

questions.question: What new covenant does God promise to make with Israel and Judah in Jeremiah 31?
options: One with God's law written in their hearts
A covenant based on external observance
A covenant through physical sacrifices only
A covenant dependent on their perfect obedience
questions.correctAnswer: One with God's law written in their hearts
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 31:33 describes a new covenant where God will put His law in their inward parts and write it in their hearts. This is echoed in Hebrews 8:10 and Ezekiel 36:26-27, highlighting the internal transformation through the Spirit rather than external adherence alone.

questions.question: In Jeremiah 31, what does God say about the knowledge of Him under the new covenant?
options: All shall know the LORD from the least to the greatest
Only the priests shall know the LORD
Knowledge of the LORD will be hidden
Only the elders shall teach of the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: All shall know the LORD from the least to the greatest
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 31:34 promises that under the new covenant all people will know the LORD personally and intimately. This universal knowledge is consistent with John 17:3, 1 John 2:20, and Isaiah 11:9.

questions.question: What reason does Jeremiah 31 give for God forgiving the iniquity of His people and remembering their sin no more?
options: Because of the new covenant and internal transformation
Because they will offer more sacrifices
Because they will rebuild the temple
Because they will follow the old covenant perfectly
questions.correctAnswer: Because of the new covenant and internal transformation
questions.explanation: In Jeremiah 31:34, God promises forgiveness and forgetting of sin as part of the new covenant where His law is internalized. This is supported by Hebrews 8:12, Isaiah 43:25, Micah 7:18-19, and Psalm 103:12.

questions.question: What does Jeremiah 31 say about individual responsibility for sin?
options: Every man shall die for his own iniquity
The children suffer for the sins of their fathers
Sin is forgiven generationally
Only priests bear the consequences of sin
questions.correctAnswer: Every man shall die for his own iniquity
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 31:29-30 teaches that individuals are responsible for their own sin, contrasting earlier collective guilt ideas. This aligns with Ezekiel 18:20, 2 Corinthians 5:10, Galatians 6:5, and Romans 14:12 emphasizing personal accountability.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 31 describe God's role towards Israel as a shepherd?
options: He gathers and keeps them like a shepherd his flock
He abandons them to their enemies
He punishes them without mercy
He ignores their wandering
questions.correctAnswer: He gathers and keeps them like a shepherd his flock
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 31:10 portrays God as a shepherd who gathers and keeps Israel securely. This shepherd imagery is consistent with Psalm 23:1, Ezekiel 34:11-16, John 10:11, and Isaiah 40:11 demonstrating God's care and guidance.

questions.question: What does Jeremiah 31 say about the restoration of the land and its people?
options: God will build and plant them again
The land will remain desolate forever
The people will be scattered without hope
Restoration depends on human effort alone
questions.correctAnswer: God will build and plant them again
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 31:4 and 31:28 affirm God’s promise to rebuild and plant Israel after judgment. This restoration theme aligns with Isaiah 61:4, Ezekiel 36:33-36, and Acts 3:21 pointing to God's sovereign renewal.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 31, what will happen to the mourning of God's people?
options: Mourning will be turned into joy
Mourning will increase without end
Mourning will remain unchanged
Mourning will be ignored by God
questions.correctAnswer: Mourning will be turned into joy
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 31:13 promises that God will turn mourning into joy, comforting His people. This is consistent with Isaiah 61:3, 2 Corinthians 1:3-4, Revelation 21:4, and Psalm 30:11 emphasizing God’s redemptive comfort.

questions.question: What new thing does God declare He will create on the earth in Jeremiah 31?
options: A woman shall compass a man
A new temple with golden gates
A river flowing from the desert
A mountain taller than Sinai
questions.correctAnswer: A woman shall compass a man
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 31:22 mentions God creating a new thing: a woman shall compass a man, which is often interpreted as a symbol of reversal or renewal in relationships. This reflects God's power to renew creation, resonating with Isaiah 43:19 and Revelation 21:5.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 31 describe God’s sovereignty over cosmic order as a guarantee of Israel’s enduring nationhood?
options: If the sun, moon, and stars fail, then Israel will cease to be a nation
If Israel fails, then the sun will stop shining
Israel’s nationhood depends on human effort
The stars control Israel’s destiny
questions.correctAnswer: If the sun, moon, and stars fail, then Israel will cease to be a nation
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 31:35-36 links the enduring nationhood of Israel to the unchanging cosmic order established by God. This teaches God's sovereign control over both creation and covenant promises, consistent with Psalm 89:37, Genesis 8:22, and Malachi 3:6.

questions.question: What is the significance of God calling Ephraim His 'firstborn' in Jeremiah 31?
options: It denotes a special, beloved status among the tribes
It means Ephraim is the only tribe chosen
It refers to Ephraim’s political dominance
It signifies Ephraim’s disobedience only
questions.correctAnswer: It denotes a special, beloved status among the tribes
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 31:9 calls Ephraim God's firstborn, indicating a favored position and special relationship, similar to Exodus 4:22, Romans 11:28, and Psalm 89:27. This emphasizes God's enduring love despite Israel's failures.

questions.question: What does Jeremiah 31 say about God's response to Ephraim's repentance?
options: God has mercy and is troubled for Ephraim
God rejects Ephraim completely
God ignores Ephraim’s repentance
God requires more sacrifices from Ephraim
questions.correctAnswer: God has mercy and is troubled for Ephraim
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 31:20 shows God’s tender mercy toward Ephraim after repentance, illustrating divine compassion. This is consistent with Joel 2:13, Hosea 11:8, Luke 15:20, and Psalm 103:13.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 31 describe the future condition of the priests and people of Israel?
options: Priests shall be satisfied with fatness and the people with goodness
Priests will be hungry and the people sorrowful
Priests will rule ruthlessly over the people
People will reject the priests entirely
questions.correctAnswer: Priests shall be satisfied with fatness and the people with goodness
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 31:14 promises satisfaction and blessing upon priests and people, signifying abundant provision and favor, aligning with Malachi 3:10, Psalm 23:5, Isaiah 25:6, and John 10:10.

questions.question: What eschatological hope does Jeremiah 31 offer regarding the captivity of Israel?
options: The children will return from the land of the enemy
Israel will remain captive forever
God will forget the captivity
Captivity is a permanent punishment
questions.correctAnswer: The children will return from the land of the enemy
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 31:16-17 promises the return of Israel’s children from captivity, reflecting God’s restoration plan. This hope is consistent with Isaiah 44:22-23, Ezra 1:1-4, Luke 1:68, and Romans 11:26.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 31 portray God’s involvement in planting and sowing Israel and Judah?
options: God will sow them with seed of man and beast
Israel and Judah will plant themselves
God abandons the planting process
Planting is only symbolic and not literal
questions.correctAnswer: God will sow them with seed of man and beast
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 31:27 describes God actively sowing the houses of Israel and Judah, symbolizing restoration and blessing, paralleling Isaiah 55:10-11, Psalm 126:5, Hosea 2:21, and 1 Corinthians 3:6.
